title.narrative: We Cannot Wait

description.narrative: In Ethiopia, EWLA will target individuals as well as groups of disadvantaged or poor women and girls of all ages ranging from secondary school to university, government officials (both men and women), members of the parliament (both men and women), and women politicians. These target individuals and groups will be approached at the national, regional and community levels urban and rural areas as per EWLA’s structure. These stakeholders will be approached based on EWLA’s record of work and previous and ongoing assessments. Stakeholders also may lack awareness on gender equality, have negligence on promoting and realisation of women rights and be constrained by budgetary needs.

The "We Cannot Wait: towards an inclusive and diverse women’s movement in the Greater Horn of Africa project represents an entirely Southern-led consortium of organizations that are explicitly focused on women’s empowerment throughout the Greater Horn of Africa (GHoA). The consortium works in the following countries: Somalia, Uganda, Sudan, South Sudan, and Ethiopia.
The project aims at strengthening women’s leadership and participation in (political) decision-making and strengthening women’s economic empowerment and improving the economic climate for women's participation. The project is targeted at women's rights activists and organizations. Project strategies include capacity building for effective advocacy, linking women's rights activists and organizations for a common agenda and action, and improving their access to advocacy platforms are among the project's tactics.
Women in the Greater Horn of Africa will be leading and defining the political, sociocultural and economic agenda through a gender lens at all levels

title.narrative: WRA/Os form an inclusive and diverse coalition with shared agendas

# of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions on women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision-making processes in public, private and civic sphere, through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or movement building at national level

comment.narrative: We will participate in the annual regional gender forums bringing together all the WROs/As from across the 5 countries. These forums will include Human Rights Council, the African Commission for Human Rights, or the Commission on the Status of Women etc
participated in one regional gender forum

title.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions on women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision-making processes in public, private and civic sphere, through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or movement building at Grassroots level

comment.narrative: Women and female youth in six regions will be supported to hold quarterly strategy meetings where paralegals, women activists, and WROs can come together and plan campaigns and strategies around lobbying and advocating on issues around women’s agency

title.narrative: WOMEN IN THE GREATER HORN OF AFRICA WILL BE LEADING AND DEFINING THE POLITICAL, SOCIOCULTURAL AND ECONOMIC AGENDA THROUGH A GENDER LENS AT ALL LEVELS.
# of laws implemented for sustainable and inclusive development

comment.narrative: Although Ethiopia is replete with a history of women’s engagement in the public and political spheres and significant progress on gender equality indices ranking 97 Globally, there are some gaps in the legal frameworks guaranteeing the rights of women to economic and political participation such as the Political Parties Registration and Election’s Code of Conduct and the Economic Reform Policy that target vulnerable groups in Ethiopian society, specifically women.

advocate and lobby for amendment of Laws including protecting women's rights to economic or political empowerment including Constitutional requirement for the representation of women in all elected and appointed political positions at all levels, amendment of the Ethiopian Electoral, Political Parties Registration and Election’s Code of Conduct

# of governmental policies implemented for sustainable and inclusive development
# of by- laws implemented for sustainable and inclusive development
# of international agreements for sustainable and inclusive development that are better implemented as a result of WRA/Os engagement
WRA/Os have strengthened advocacy and lobbying skills Activities: Activity: Advocacy and Lobbying
# WROs with strengthened advocacy and lobbying skills
# WRAs/Individuals with increased capacity on women rights based approaches
Intermediate Outcome: 1.1WRA/Os are able to lead and take transformative leadership positions
# of individuals (female) with improved attitudes and practices towards women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision-making processes

comment.narrative: Very few women interviewed reported a positive attitude towards women's voice, agency, leadership and representation in decision making processes. 2/19 reported to have ever participated in political campaigns. Additionally, None reported to have run for political office; 5/19 reported they are interested in political affairs, 6/19 reported having knowledge on both electoral and governance process and only 7/19 perceive that the political process is fair for women.

We will work towards reducing the barriers to women's participation in decision making processes including lack of access to economic opportunities, lack of information on on existing laws that promote women's participation in decision making processes.

Intermediate Outcome 1.2: WRA/Os are able to propose legal and policy reforms (Diseggregated by type)
# international agreements improved to eradicate all forms of violence against women and young women in public and private life

comment.narrative: Ethiopia signed the Maputo Protocol on 01/06/2004 however they have not ratified the same. Ethiopia ratified CEDAW in 1981 and has submitted the 8 periodic reports.
We will work towards ratification of the Maputo Protocol.
